metadata.title: Removal of dyes by a new nano–TiO2 ultrafiltration membrane deposited on low-cost support prepared from natural Moroccan bentonite

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Applied Clay Science
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/clay
Research paper
Removal of dyes by a new nano–TiO2 ultrafiltration membrane deposited on low-cost support prepared from natural Moroccan bentonite
Abdelmjid Bouazizia,⁎, Majda Breidaa, Brahim Achioua, Mohamed Ouammoua, José Ignacio Calvob, Abdelah Aaddanea, Saad Alami Younssia
a Laboratory of Materials Membranes and Environment, Chemistry Department, Faculty of Sciences and Technologies, University of Hassan II, Mohammedia, Casablanca, Morocco b SMAP (Surfaces and Porous Materials Group), Applied Physics Department, ETSIIAA, University of Valladolid, Palencia, Spain
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Moroccan bentonite Ceramic membrane Ultrafiltration Dye removal
A B S T R A C T
This paper reports the preparation and characterization of a low-cost nano-TiO2 ultrafiltration membrane deposited on a bentonite support. The ultrafiltration layer was obtained by dip-coating process using nano-TiO2, followed by sintering at 750 °C. Environmental Scanning Electron Microscope (ESEM) analysis of prepared ultrafiltration membrane showed that the deposited layer is homogeneous and shows a good adhesion on the support presenting a mean thickness of 4 ± 0.2 μm. The average pore diameter and water permeability of the obtained membrane are respectively 10 ± 0.5 nm and 16.08 L/h m2 bar. The membrane performance was evaluated by filtration of three different dyes: two anionic (Direct red 80 and Acid orange 74) and a cationic one (Methylene blue). Effect of feed pH and dyes concentration on membrane rejection was investigated at a pressure of 4 bar. The experimental filtration results showed that rejection of Direct Red 80, Acid Orange 74 and Methylene Blue achieved maximum values of 98%, 85% and 94% respectively, depending on filtration conditions and each dye characteristics.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Safe water supply and environmental protection of water reserves have become two major preoccupations for many countries. Currently, many regions in Morocco, rest of Maghreb and most of Mediterranean countries are experiencing a problem of water shortage (Barrouk et al., 2015). This lack of water has been aggravated by the irrational use of natural resources and the rapid industrialization of the exposed areas. Given the gravity of the problem, it is necessary to consider adequate solutions to solve it.
Textile, paper and plastic industries have often rejected colored wastewater without previous treatment. On the other hand, most of the dyes used in the textile industries are stable and resistible to ultraviolet light (they are not degraded due to sun rays attack) as well they are not biodegradable (Saffaj et al., 2004). They are also impervious to aerobic digestion, making these dyes long term water pollutants. To minimize the risk of environmental pollution, it becomes necessary to treat dye effluents before discharging them into water streams (Baraka et al., 2014).
Several physicochemical techniques have been used to treat these dye effluents eliminating their contaminants, including solicitation,
sedimentation, impaction, interception, adhesion, chemical adsorption, physical adsorption, flocculation and biological growth (Chinoune et al., 2016; Luo and Nguyen, 2017; Shi et al., 2006).
Membrane technology has shown potentiality in the separation of dyes by microfiltration (MF), ultrafiltration (UF) and nanofiltration (NF) (Jana et al., 2010; Aouni et al., 2012; Liu et al., 2017) and it is increasingly used in industrial processes such as water treatment. Therefore, the use of membrane technology could replace or at least minimize in a short future the conventional separation and purification techniques in many industrial processes, thus reducing the whole amount of energy being consumed (Seffaj et al., 2005).
In recent years, industrial applications of porous ceramic membranes have attracted more and more the attention of scientific community. This interest is due to their numerous benefits such as better thermal, chemical and mechanical resistance and controllable microstructure (Ezziane et al., 2010). However, the use of composite ceramic membranes for wastewater treatment is still limited due to the high price of ceramic membranes.
Looking for the economic feasibility of the use of membranes in many wastewater recovery applications, the development of low-cost ceramic membranes based on natural materials and some other waste

materials was investigated by several authors (Medjemem et al., 2016; Bouazizi et al., 2017; Achiou et al., 2016, 2017; Fatimah et al., 2015; Liu et al., 2016). Barrouk et al. (2015) and Khemakhem et al. (2015) elaborated and characterized ceramic membranes made from a mixture of natural and synthetic phosphates. Saffaj et al. (2006) described the elaboration of an UF membrane deposited on a support prepared from natural Moroccan clay. In other work (Saffaj et al., 2005), they used a macroporous substrate made of Moroccan clay as support for an intermediate ZrO2 layer and then a TiO2/ZnAl2O4 UF layer; and tested it for the separation of mineral salts. Kumar et al. (2015) fabricated a composite membrane of zirconia by in-situ hydrothermal technique whish was applied for separation of methyl orange.
In order to ameliorate the flux through the membrane, the use of nano-scale additives as TiO2, ZrO2, Al2O3 and SiO2, serves to enhance the hydrophilic character of the membrane, (Kocherginsky et al., 2003; Chang et al., 2014; Xu et al., 2016). There exist many methods for preparation of ceramic UF membranes. The sol-gel method is widely described in the literature. Especially, the colloidal sol–gel route is preferred due to its advantages of low volatilization and easy operation. However, few works have been reported regarding the preparation of UF membranes using the colloidal sol route (Zhang et al., 2017).
A variety of nanoparticles such as ZrO2 (Zhai et al., 2006), Al2O3 (Widjojo et al., 2008), and TiO2 (Li et al., 2016) are directly blended with dope solutions, which are known a simple and useful route to prepare a hybrid membrane.
Titanium oxide is commonly used as additive for making mineral membranes because it has a very good resistance to acids (HCl, HNO3, H3PO4 …) and bases (NaOH, KOH …). On the other hand, the role of TiO2 is to adjust permeability and increase the hydrophobicity of the membrane. (Leong et al., 2014).
According to this point of view, we have focused on the development of low-cost inorganic membranes presenting as interesting feature their low-cost. In a previous work (Bouazizi et al., 2017), obtained a UF membrane by depositing a TiO2 layer by spin-coating on a ceramic support made from bentonite and micronized phosphate. The resulting membrane was successfully tested to filtrate Direct Red 80 solutions.
Another approach is reported in this paper. To this aim, a bentonite MF support was used to develop an UF layer made of nano-TiO2 particles in aqueous media by using the colloidal solution destabilization technique. The thin-layer of nano-TiO2 was deposited by dip-coating method. Then, the separation performance of resulting membrane was investigated by soluble dyes removal (Direct Red 80, Acid Orange and Methylene Blue). In addition, various operating conditions such as pressure and feed concentration were studied.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Raw materials
sections.text:
Bentonite was collected from Nador (Morocco). The raw material was dried in the stove at 100 °C for 24 h, grinded in a ball mill and sieved through a sieve of 45 μm. The chemical analysis of the raw bentonite showed that siliceous (SiO2) and aluminous (Al2O3) material are the most significant components of bentonite. The montmorillonite is the major mineral compound of the bentonite. The characteristics of raw bentonite powder were detailed in our previous paper (Bouazizi et al., 2016).
Anatase Titanium (IV) oxide nanoparticles (TiO2, ≥99.5% purity), with a nominal average diameter of 21 nm and 65 m2/g of surface area and cetytrimethylammonium bromide (C16H33N (CH3)3 Br) (CTAB), were used as acquired from Sigma–Aldrich without further purification. Poly-vinyl alcohol (PVA), 99% was acquired from Prolabo.
The soluble dyes used for filtration test were Direct Red 80 (DR 80), Acid Orange 74 (AO 74) and Methylene Blue (MB); and they were acquired from Sigma-Aldrich. Fig. 1 shows the chemical structures of
these tested dyes.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. Bentonite support
sections.text: The ceramic support used in this work, as a basis to deposit an UF layer, is made from natural bentonite by pressing method followed by sintering at 950 °C (Bouazizi et al., 2016). The characteristics of bentonite support are described in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Preparation of the nano-TiO2 membrane
sections.text:
The UF layer was prepared from nano-TiO2 powder by a dip-coating process at room temperature. The colloidal solution was prepared by dispersing of 3.00 g of nano-TiO2 in 66.00 g of deionized water. Then, 0.05 g of CTAB added as surfactant. The mixture was stirred for 2 h using magnetic agitation and followed by 30 min of ultrasonic treatment. 1 g of nitric acid (2 M) and 30 g of PVA solution (12 wt% aqueous solution) were added under strong stirring to the mixture as peptizing agent and binder respectively. Finally, the resulting dispersion was exposed again to ultrasonic radiation during 15 min followed by 30 min of rigorous stir before use.
One face of flat bentonite support was polished by abrasive paper in order to obtain a smooth surface and then cleaned by distilled water. The other face of the support was covered by Teflon paper. And then support was vertically dipped into the colloidal solution for coating during 30 min. After retracting back, the resulting membrane was finally dried for 24 h at 80 °C and thermally treated. The thermal program applied was essentially composed by the plateau of 2 h at 300 °C to eliminate completely PVA, and sintering step at 750 °C during 3 h. A 0.5 °C/min heating rate was used between plateaus to prevent the formation of cracks.

sections.heading: 2.2. Membrane characterization
sections.text:
Several characterization techniques were used to determine the characteristics of prepared nano-TiO2 UF membrane.
A microscopic analysis was performed using a Quanta 200 FEG Environmental-SEM (FEI Company, USA) for imaging the surfaces of resulting nano-TiO2 membrane.
The surface roughness is one of the most important characteristics of ceramic membranes. It influences the adsorption/desorption of species on the membrane surface and therefore affects its clogging. For the case of hydrophilic membranes, there is a close relationship between membrane surface characteristics and fouling (Bouazizi et al., 2017; Madaeni et al., 2013). On the other hand, pure water flux increases when roughness increases, due to a corresponding increase of surface area of the asymmetric membrane (Vatanpour et al., 2012; Peng et al., 2004). For this reason determining the surface roughness becomes necessary. Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) was employed to study the surface roughness of the elaborated UF membrane. A Mobile AFM microscope from Nanosurf (Switzerland) was used, with 133 kHz resonant frequency. Small squares of the membrane (approximately 1 cm2) were cut and glued on a glass substrate.
The pore size distribution of the membrane was obtained by N2 adsorption-desorption experiments at a temperature of 77 K (TristarII 3020, Micromeritics, USA). To validate these results, they were compared with image analysis of the ESEM membrane surface pictures performed by using ImageJ software.
Hydrophilicity is one of the most important properties of the nanoTiO2 membrane which influences its flux, its resistance to become fouled. A membrane with lower water contact angle deliberately manifests better hydrophilic properties (Shokri et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2016) and presents lower fouling degrees for similar experimental conditions. This hydrophilicity of membrane is generally expressed in terms of the contact angle for a water drop on the membrane surface. Therefore, the hydrophilicity of our membrane was investigated by contact angle measurement (PGX, Thwing-Albert Instrument Co.) by using the image analyzer software provided with the device. After three
measurements of deionized water contact angle at different locations in the membrane surface, results were averaged.
In the filtration of dyes which is the final aim of the membrane here developed, the relative charge affinity from dye molecules to membrane surface will play an important role on explaining the rejections found, so characterizing the charges of the membrane will be convenient. The point of zero charges (pHPZC) can be used to characterize a membrane since it indicates the pH at which of the membrane has a zero surface charge. The determination of zero charge point (pHPZC) was performed according to the solid addition method (Ahmad et al., 2009). The value of pHPZC can be determined from the curve that cuts the initial pH (pHi) line of the plot pHf–pHi vs pHi (being pHf the final value of pH).

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Filtration test
sections.text:
The efficiency of the prepared nano-TiO2 membrane was evaluated by cross-flow filtration of several soluble dyes commonly used in textile industry.
The experimental set-up used for the filtration test is illustrated in Fig. 2. The membrane was preliminarily immersed in distilled water for 24 h and then placed in the membrane housing with 5.30 cm2 of effective filtration area. Feed solution was pumped tangentially to the membrane while transmembrane pressure was maintained constant through the pressure gauge and the corresponding regulation valve. Permeate was collected in a balance, so the filtration rate could be
determined over time. It should be mentioned that all filtration experiments were conducted at room temperature, and the cooling system was used only to avoid an excessive heating of the solution due to pumping.
The water permeability, Lp (L/h m2 bar), of the membrane was determined by measuring the permeate flux of distilled water, Jw (L/ h m2), as function of transmembrane pressure, ΔP (bar), which was varied from 0 to 6 bar. Flux and permeability were calculated by the following equations (Eq. (1) and Eq. (2)):

The rejection test experiments for DR 80, AO 74 and MB were conducted at transmembrane pressure of 4 bar during 2 h. The effect of feed pH on dyes rejection was studied in the range from pH 3.0 to pH 9.5 at a feed concentration of 50 ppm. sections.heading: 2.3.2. Analytical methods
sections.text:
The permeate concentration was measured by UV spectrophotometry (Cambridge Sci., UK) using quartz cells. All measurements were made at the wavelength corresponding to the maximum of absorbance (λmax) for each dye. The maximum wavelength used for DR 80, AO 74 and MB were respectively 528, 455 and 664 nm. The pH of the solution was measured by radiometer pH Meter (CyberScan PC 300).
Fig. 1. Dyes formulae: (a) Direct Red 80, (b) Acid Orange 74 and (c) Methylene Blue.

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Membrane morphology
sections.text: Fig. 3 shows ESEM pictures for top-view and cross-section of prepared membrane. The figure reveals that the surface layer is homogeneous and shows a good adhesion on the support. The membrane has relatively rough surface in comparison with other similar membranes (Cortalezzi et al., 2003; Zhu et al., 2015). The membrane thickness was found about 4 ± 0.2 μm.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Pore size distribution
sections.text:

An overall amount higher than 300 pores was examined in order to determine the pore size distribution. Accordingly, the average pore size (d (nm)) was calculated using the following Eq. (4):

figure, it can be noted that the majority of pores are placed in the range from 9 to 12 nm, resulting in quite narrow pore size distributions. The mean pore diameter of the resulting membrane as obtained from image analysis was 11 ± 1 nm. While, the pore size analysis from N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm resulted in a mean pore diameter of 10 ± 0.5 nm. It should be noted the good agreement between both

sections.heading: 3.1.3. AFM force spectroscopy
sections.text: In the AFM study, both 2 dimensional (2D) and 3 dimensional (3D) images have been included to get a better picture of UF membrane at the porous surface of the membrane (Fig. 5a, b). AFM images of the UF membrane were recorded using a scanned area of 541 nm× 541 nm. The mean surface roughness (Ra) of the membrane has been determined from the deep profile of several lines as that shown in Fig. 5c. One of these profiles is shown in Fig. 5, and resulted in roughness variation in the range from 14.30 to 20 nm. Of course, apart from determining the surface roughness, the AFM scans of the UF membrane can be used for the determination of individual pore sizes (Madaeni et al., 2013). This analysis was done for some selected pores and the obtained pore diameters were in the range from 10 to 20 nm, confirming previous results from ESEM and N2 adsorption/desorption. Nevertheless the measurement of individual pores from AFM is less accurate than other pore size determinations as the number of pores obtained from a line profile is quite low and a big number of lines should be analyzed to get a reliable pore size distribution.

sections.heading: 3.1.4. Contact angle measurement
sections.text: An example of picture showing a water droplet onto the surface and the contact angle measured after a certain period of time is shown in Fig. 6. The average value of the nano-TiO2 membrane was found to be 42 ± 1°. Then the membrane can be considered as slightly hydrophilic.

sections.heading: 3.1.5. Point of zero charge
sections.text:
The nano-TiO2 membrane surface is expected to have a positive charge at pH < pHPZC. However at pH > pHPZC, the surface should be negatively charged (Fig. 7).
Results of pHPZC are shown in Fig. 8. At extreme values of pH, the change of pH after addition to the membrane is almost nil, but in the middle range of pH there is a clear change of sign in the pH increment
revealing that the overall charge of the membrane surface changes from negative to positive. Then, the pH value of zero charges for the nanoTiO2 was determined as 5.7 which is consisted with that found by Kosmulski (2016).

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Water permeability
sections.text: Results of distilled water flux vs. Pressure are displayed in Fig. 9, where a clear linear dependency of flux with pressure is found, in accordance with Darcy's law. From the slope of such plot the value of water permeability is about 16.08 L/h m2 bar.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Filtration of dyes
sections.text:
Membrane here developed could be used to treat textile effluents that were generally charged (due to the presence of soluble dyes) in order to reuse water and/or to recover valuable species (Akbari et al., 2002). In this context, discoloring of solutions containing DR 80, AO 74 and MB by using developed nano-TiO2 membrane was studied. To
Fig. 5. AFM micrographs of the surface of the UF membrane, (a) 2D, (b) 3D views and (d) analysis of height profile of the cross section across the dashed line shown in (c).
analyze properly these results, anionic and cationic dyes behavior will be separately discussed.
3.2.2.1. Filtration of anionic dyes. The behavior of the rejection of anionic dyes (DR 80 and AO 74) was evaluated, as a function of feed pH and initial concentration of dyes.
3.2.2.1.1. pH effect. Fig. 10 shows the evolution of flux and rejection of DR 80 and AO 74 as a function of feed pH, both in the range from pH 3.0 to pH 9.5. The behavior of both dyes is quite similar with a continuous increase of rejection as pH increases. This increase goes from 60.9% to 95.4% in the case of DR 80, while for AO 74 the increase goes from 49.6 to 85.3%. The strong rejection observed, higher than expected from the small size of both molecules, cannot be
explained by pure sieving mechanism. In this case, it should be taken into account the electrostatic interactions between membrane surface containing several charged groups and the dye molecules which also charged.
At low pH values, the membrane (as discussed in Section 3.1.5) presents a net positive charge while the dye molecules are negatively charged. This results in a strong attraction of dyes for the membrane surface where many of these dye molecules occupy possible adsorption sites. While the rest of the molecules pass freely through the pores, then leading to a low dye rejection. As pH increases the membrane charges changes to negative (over zero charge point) and therefore the electrostatic interaction between membrane and solute molecules become repulsive, resulting in a clearly higher rejection of solutes. The same result was observed by Akbari et al. (2002), Seffaj et al. (2005). Finally, the higher values of rejection for DR 80 as compared with that showed by AO 74 are related with their respective sizes, being DR 80 a bigger molecule (MW = 1373.1 Da) than AO 74 (MW = 508.36 Da).
3.2.2.1.2. Concentration effect. The influence of initial dye concentration on rejection and flux was studied by filtering the two anionic dyes at their natural pH (pH 6.8 for DR 80 and pH 6.2 for AO 74), and a constant pressure of 4 bar. These results are shown in Fig. 11 for both DR 80 and AO 74. There is a constant trend of increasing retentions as concentration increases, while flux behavior is opposite. The higher the concentration the lower the flux measured.
This behavior is not strange as it is well known that batch filtration theory predicts (in the case of solute retention) that flux should decrease with higher feed concentration. This theory leads to a logarithmic relation between flux and solute concentration, (Hilal et al., 2007; Antón et al., 2015). So, the logarithmic plots of flux and retention data vs. concentration are reasonably linear (Fig. 11). Certainly, concentration polarization phenomenon (accumulation of rejected dyes on membrane surface) is not enough to completely explain the

Fig. 8. Determination of the pHPZC for nano-TiO2 membrane.

experimental behavior. Therefore we can suppose there are more effects leading to an increase of retention and decrease of flux. A possible explanation could be the presence of some dye aggregation (Lin et al., 2016; Hamada et al., 1991; Bouazizi et al., 2017), being this aggregation more effective as concentration of molecules increases.
Therefore, this initial rejection possibly could enhance the formation of a secondary polarization layer in the form of a gel which plays an additional role of resistance to the permeation of dye molecules (Yu et al., 2012; Hamada et al., 1991). On the other side, the evolution of flux is somehow the contrary, with a continuous decrease as pH increases, but not so pronounced as the change in rejection.
Finally, the variations of flux and rejection of dyes AO 74 and DR 80 as a function of time are shown in Fig. 12. The flux rate decline over time can be explained by the formation of layer of retained particles which reduces the permeability of the whole membrane (Bouazizi et al., 2017). Regarding the behavior of rejection, it also decreases with time, which can be related with the role of adsorption on membrane rejection. Therefore, rejection is higher in the initial filtration times when more adsorption sites are available. As filtration time passes, these sites become occupied reducing the resulting rejection of dye molecules. On the other side, the fact that performance of the membrane, both in terms of flux and rejection, does not show a very high decrease after> 2 h of filtration (lower than 20% of the original values) can assure that the membrane here developed will be a good candidate to use in dye recovery. Certainly, long term experiments should be needed
to assure optimal behavior in an industrial process, but the trends here showed are certainly promising.

sections.heading: 3.2.2.2. Filtration of cationic dye (MB)
sections.text:
3.2.2.2.1. pH effect. The evolution of MB (50 ppm) flux and rejection as a function of pH through the UF membrane is shown in Fig. 13. The rejection rate of MB decreases by 93.5% at pH 3 to 50.4% around pH 9.5, while flux increases slightly in the whole range of pH. Certainly, the explanation of this behavior should be the opposite that in the case of anionic dyes. As the pH increases the membrane becomes more negatively charged. It results in lower repulsion with cationic dye molecules, and also lower rejection of molecules. This effect of pH is not so pronounced for flux, which is mainly governed by the water molecules passage and not very strongly influenced by rejection of solute.
It is worth noting that at very acid pH values, the rejection of MB is comparable to that found for DR 80 (in the opposite pH range) and clearly higher than that of AO 74, in spite of being a smaller molecule. But again this high value of retention only serves to reinforce the idea that rejection is more related with the presence of electrostatic interactions which overcome the steric factor on explaining the separation performance of the membrane for the different dyes.
Moreover, the interesting point is that the behavior of all dye molecules in the range of pH where maximum attraction to the membrane can be found (acid pH for MB and very basic for DR 80 and AO 74). In this case, the key role is played by the molecule size, then lowest rejection is found for the smallest molecule (MB), while the biggest one (DR 80) presents the highest rejection value.
3.2.2.2.2. Concentration effect. Fig. 14 shows the evolution of the rejection and flux as a function of the concentration at natural solution pH (pH 5.2). Similarly to that in Fig. 11, data were plotted in a logarithmic X-scale. An almost linear relation between flux (or rejection) and logarithm of concentration was found. In general, a high concentration leads to higher accumulation of retained particles in the feed side of the membrane then contribution to concentration polarization effect and thus to a flow decrease. For MB, the flux decreases from 46.23 to 36.53 L/h.m2 when the concentration increases from 20 to 100 ppm. Similarly, rejection is increased, also found for anionic dyes. In any case both trends: flux reduction and increasing rejection have been quite often reported by different authors. (Saffaj et al., 2004, 2005; Akbari et al., 2002).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
A nano-TiO2 UF membrane was successfully prepared by dipcoating process followed by sintering process at 750 °C for 3 h. The
nano-TiO2 dispersion was prepared in an aqueous media using the colloidal solution destabilization technique. ESEM measurement showed that the surface of the TiO2 layer is uniform and smooth, indicating that the slipping time and the corresponding deposited thickness of UF membrane were adequately chosen. The prepared membrane presented a mean pore size of 10 ± 0.5 nm and a pure water permeability of 16.08 L/h·m2·bar. Filtration results showed that anionic dyes (DR 80 and AO 74) are more rejected in alkaline medium. On the contrary, cationic dye (MB) is greatly rejected in acid medium. In addition, higher concentration leads to higher dyes rejection values. Finally the rejection behavior of the membrane for the differently charged dyes can be explained in terms of the membrane Zero Charge Point (PZC), determined as 5.7, and the sign of the overall membrane charge under or over such PZC. Anionic and cationic dyes rejection behaves oppositely when pH passes PZC in accordance with the respective membrane and dyes charges. These electrostatic interactions results in very high retentions that cannot be explained from a pure sieving mechanism.

metadata.abstractText: This paper reports the preparation and characterization of a low-cost nano-TiO2 ultrafiltration membrane deposited on a bentonite support. The ultrafiltration layer was obtained by dip-coating process using nano-TiO2, followed by sintering at 750 °C. Environmental Scanning Electron Microscope (ESEM) analysis of prepared ultrafiltration membrane showed that the deposited layer is homogeneous and shows a good adhesion on the support presenting a mean thickness of 4 ± 0.2 μm. The average pore diameter and water permeability of the obtained membrane are respectively 10 ± 0.5 nm and 16.08 L/h m bar. The membrane performance was evaluated by filtration of three different dyes: two anionic (Direct red 80 and Acid orange 74) and a cationic one (Methylene blue). Effect of feed pH and dyes concentration on membrane rejection was investigated at a pressure of 4 bar. The experimental filtration results showed that rejection of Direct Red 80, Acid Orange 74 and Methylene Blue achieved maximum values of 98%, 85% and 94% respectively, depending on filtration conditions and each dye characteristics.
